column19: 24/ If your company has a data model, and you are curious about how you can use external data to increase the precision, recall or accuracy of your model, go to https://t.co/dZ6dq36Qjm
column20: 23/ And best of all, it takes away the biased, limited way of thinking that we humans have. The most amazing thing is when the system finds a way to improve your model based on a dataset that you would have never thought of on your own. I’ve seen it happen and it’s wild.
column21: 22/ Given a model, Explorium scours the mass of data sources & automatically surfaces the most relevant, most predictive data products out there. You can quickly sort thru tens of thousands of answers, most of which you didn’t know existed, & bring them right into your model.
column22: 21/ Today - when you ask a question in google - it answers with the top, most informative and most relevant pages. From billions of page options, even the ones (most of the ones) that you didn’t know actually existed. The same concept could and should be applied to data science.
column23: 20/ Let me try another analogy: Before search engines, it was tougher to find stuff. There were a huge variety of valuable sites, but they were not organized in an approachable way to get what you needed. You couldn’t leverage the info & and worse, you had to know where to look.
column24: 19/ Once I saw it, I realized the huge implications for data scientists, for risk and fraud officers, for data and analytics leaders, for marketing leaders and for companies in general. The product gives you an answer to: “how can we make it better?”
column25: 18/ The demo of the live product is insanely great: https://t.co/0sBRkYL69V and it made us want to invest on the spot.
column26: 17/ This is what Explorium does. It is an automated data science platform that connects you to the data you need for better decision making. My simple mind calls it “an appstore for data” but, there may be better ways to describe it.
column27: 16/ You need a way to test this data on your predictive model to see if it shows uplift, and then easily subscribe/pay for this dataset that you deem makes a difference for your data model. You also want reliability in the data quality.
column28: 15/ You need a way browse the catalog of *tens of thousands* of public datasets, get recommendations of which of those datasets might be able to help, allowing the data scientist or the analyst to select from verified high quality data providers…
column29: 14/ Like the Appstore example, there is a need to organize against this data science problem...
column30: 13/ The finance institution could be using other signals: did they get government funding (public dataset) so it has a better chance of surviving? Is the business selling online or not? All things you can get through data feeds.
column31: 12/ As we're seeing around us - that no longer is relevant to judging whether a SMB will be a good credit risk.
column32: 11/ Here’s another example: Small business lending. If you are a financial institution, when you grant credit, you use financial signals to drive your risk model. Things like revenue growth, spend, etc.
column33: 10/ Being able to quickly find and utilize the right data will enable you as a retailer to not only adapt very quickly - but to be predictive and possibly even gain market share.
column34: 9/ Instead a myriad of external signals are now more impactful. Maybe it’s covid cases around you, maybe it is the number of competitors going out of business, the state restrictions, the general age of the population you’re in, or a ton of other datasets.
column35: 8/ Here are a couple real examples of why this matters... Let’s say you have a retail store. The world has changed on you so fast that your old internal data and patterns (your “historical sales” data) are totally irrelevant.
column36: 7/ So, brings up an interesting question: Could you do the same with data (not the PII kind, but the public kind)? Could you create an app store for data? An appstore for data that lets you discover/browse and be recommended datasets that you can install right into your model.
column37: 6/ Bad analogy alert! This is sort of the same problem that the App Stores have solved: they helped organize the world of apps to make them easier to discover, and have a system to make them easily testable, installable and usable, and enabled flow.
column38: 5/ And w COVID, it may be that your own internal data may not even be as relevant as it once was, since “everything’s different now.”
